Will the lure of DRC's immense natural riches encourage Europe, China and the US to intervene? (Cash flow always matters more than blood flow)
Will the united opposition remain united? Unity is a very rare thing in a land with more than 250 distinct ethnic groups.

Over the last five years fatalities in the DRC, as tracked by ACLED (a US Government sponsored organization) have fallen roughly between 1,000 and 2,000 per year.  With some exceptions (e.g. the discovery of a mass grave last year containing 450 corpses), most violent incidents result in few casualties and the combatants range widely (though government security forces, unsurprisingly, are generally involved in the higher casualty events.)  While violence may increase in 2016 over 2015 (and preceding years) due to election violence or spillover from Burundi civil unrest, a mass killing against a single group that results in 1,000 noncombatant casualties is a tall order.  If the elections take an especially ethnic tone or if the Burundi government perceives elements of the DRC population is willfully harboring rebels (especially after a significant violent event), the probability of mass killing will increase.

The DRC has been witness to terrible tragedy over the last 2 decades. Last couple of years seem to be getting (relatively) better. Some rebel groups have turned in their guns in exchange for political cooperation. Kabila has been in power since the end of the 2nd Congolese civil war, and has been consolidating his power vis-a-vis governor elections. This has will likely strengthen his hold on security forces, which could discourage new rebel groups from intervening. Although it's hard to tell how solid the security forces are, as Congo strongmen have historically maintained power through a divide and conquer strategy that weakens state institutions, including security forces.

At least seventy armed groups are believed to be currently operating in the eastern region of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Despite the stabilizing presence of nineteen thousand UN peacekeepers, the stronger militant groups in the region, like the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR) and the Ugandan Allied Democratic Forces (ADF), continue to terrorize communities and control weakly governed areas of the country, financing their activities by exploiting the country’s rich natural resources. Millions of civilians have been forced to flee the fighting: the United Nations estimates that currently there are at least 2.7 million internally displaced persons in the DRC and approximately 430,000 DRC refugees from in other nations.

DRC experienced an onset of mass killings in 2015 and is currently rated with the highest risk for an onset and likely increase in 2016.
